questions.text: In the anatomical arrangement of intermuscular spaces such as the cubital fossa, femoral triangle, anatomical snuff box, etc., what primarily forms the roof of these spaces? Skin Superficial fascia Subcutaneous fat, cutaneous nerves and vessels Deep fascia
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1,2,3,4

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Intermuscular spaces , like the cubital fossa , femoral triangle , and anatomical snuff box , have a characteristic anatomical arrangement . The roof of these intermuscular space is formed layer by layer from following structures .
  • • Intermuscular spaces , like the cubital fossa , femoral triangle , and anatomical snuff box , have a characteristic anatomical arrangement .

  • • Skin - In this layer hair & skin appendages are present. Superficial fascia - In this layer subcutaneous fat , cutaneous nerves and vessels are present. Deep fascia - It is a dense , fibrous connective tissue layer , loaded with collagen , that surrounds and separates muscle groups , providing structural support and defining the boundaries of these anatomical regions .

questions.text: Concept of “Anatomical Position” is very essential for all kind of operative procedure and to understand and publish the articles. About anatomical position, which of the following statements is true?

options.label: A
options.text: The Palms of the Hands are facing Posteriorly.

options.label: C
options.text: The Feet are dorsiflexed at the ankles.

questions.correct_answer: B. The Thumb’s are oriented laterally.
questions.explanation:
Ans.  B) The Thumbs are oriented Laterally.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. The palms of the hands are facing anteriorly , not posteriorly. This allows for a clear view of the anatomical structures of the body.
  • • Option A.
  • • palms of the hands
  • • facing anteriorly
  • • allows
  • • clear view
  • • Option C. The feet are not dorsiflexed at the ankles in the anatomical position. Instead, they are in a neutral position , with the toes pointing forward .
  • • Option C.
  • • neutral position
  • • toes pointing forward
  • • Option D. The elbows are not fully flexed; they are extended in the anatomical position. This extension allows for accurate descriptions of the upper limb’s anatomical relationships .
  • • Option D.
  • • extended
  • • accurate descriptions
  • • upper limb’s anatomical relationships

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after falling onto her outstretched hand. She complains of severe pain in her elbow. Physical examination reveals swelling and tenderness over the distal humerus. An X-ray confirms a supracondylar fracture. Upon further examination, the patient is unable to flex her thumb. Which nerve is most likely involved in this patient's presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Anterior Interosseous Nerve

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Deep Branch of Ulnar Nerve :
  • • Option A. Deep Branch of Ulnar Nerve
  • • The deep branch of the ulnar nerve primarily innervates the intrinsic muscles of the hand ( excluding the thenar muscles and lateral two lumbricals ). It is involved in the adduction and abduction of fingers, and some aspects of thumb movements , but not primarily responsible for thumb flexion. Injuries to the ulnar nerve typically result in symptoms such as a "claw hand" deformity and sensory loss in the medial side of the hand, not specifically an inability to flex the thumb.
  • • The deep branch of the ulnar nerve primarily innervates the intrinsic muscles of the hand ( excluding the thenar muscles and lateral two lumbricals ).

  • • excluding

  • • It is involved in the adduction and abduction of fingers, and some aspects of thumb movements , but not primarily responsible for thumb flexion.
  • • involved
  • • adduction
  • • abduction
  • • thumb movements
  • • Injuries to the ulnar nerve typically result in symptoms such as a "claw hand" deformity and sensory loss in the medial side of the hand, not specifically an inability to flex the thumb.
  • • Injuries
  • • ulnar nerve
  • • "claw hand" deformity
  • • sensory loss
  • • medial side
  • • Option B. Posterior Interosseous Nerve :
  • • Option B. Posterior Interosseous Nerve
  • • The posterior interosseous nerve is a branch of the radial nerve . It primarily innervates the extensor muscles of the forearm . Damage to this nerve results in an inability to extend the fingers and the wrist (wrist drop) , not an inability to flex the thumb.
  • • The posterior interosseous nerve is a branch of the radial nerve .
  • • radial nerve
  • • It primarily innervates the extensor muscles of the forearm .
  • • innervates
  • • extensor muscles
  • • forearm
  • • Damage to this nerve results in an inability to extend the fingers and the wrist (wrist drop) , not an inability to flex the thumb.
  • • Damage
  • • inability
  • • extend
  • • fingers
  • • wrist (wrist drop)
  • • Option D. Superficial Branch of Ulnar Nerve :
  • • Option D. Superficial Branch of Ulnar Nerve
  • • The superficial branch of the ulnar nerve primarily provides sensory innervation to the medial one and a half fingers and the associated palm area . It does not play a significant role in motor control of the thumb, particularly in flexion.
  • • The superficial branch of the ulnar nerve primarily provides sensory innervation to the medial one and a half fingers and the associated palm area .

  • ➤ Anterior interosseous nerve is deep branch of the median nerve, innervates the flexor pollicis longus , the lateral half of the flexor digitorum profundus , and the pronator quadratus . Injury to this nerve leads to deficits in flexion of the thumb and the distal phalanges of the index and middle fingers , often assessed by the "pinch grip" test where the patient is unable to make an "OK" sign ( forming a circle with the thumb and index finger ).

questions.text: A 67-year-old female told her physician that she could walk only 60 yards per day, following which she developed a cramp like pain, fatigue, heaviness in her left side lower thigh and calf. Unable to continue her walk, she was forced to rest. After a thorough physical examination, a diagnosis of severe intermittent claudication of the left lower limb was made. Which of the following statements is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Femoral Pulse Normal in Both Limbs

options.label: B
options.text: The Popliteal, Posterior Tibial, and Dorsalis Pedis pulses were present in the Right Leg and completely absent in the Left Leg

options.label: C
options.text: Arteriography revealed a Blockage of the Left Femoral Artery at the level of the Adductor Tubercle

options.label: D
options.text: The Perforating Branches of the Profunda Femoris Artery did not participate in the Collateral Circulation around the Blocked Femoral Artery

questions.correct_answer: D. The Perforating Branches of the Profunda Femoris Artery did not participate in the Collateral Circulation around the Blocked Femoral Artery
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) The Perforating Branches of the Profunda Femoris Artery did not participate in the Collateral Circulation around the Blocked Femoral Artery

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. In cases of intermittent claudication , the femoral pulse may still be palpable if the blockage is distal to the site where the pulse is assessed . The presence of a normal femoral pulse does not exclude the possibility of arterial blockages in more distal areas of the leg.
  • • Option A.
  • • intermittent claudication
  • • femoral pulse
  • • palpable
  • • blockage
  • • distal
  • • pulse
  • • assessed
  • • Option B. The absence of pulses in the popliteal , posterior tibial , and dorsalis pedis arteries in the left leg suggests a significant obstruction in the arterial supply to this limb , while their presence in the right leg indicates normal blood flow there.
  • • Option B.

  • • pulses
  • • popliteal
  • • posterior tibial
  • • dorsalis pedis arteries
  • • left leg
  • • significant obstruction
  • • arterial supply
  • • limb
  • • presence
  • • right leg
  • • Option C . A blockage in the left femoral artery at the level of the adductor tubercle could lead to reduced blood flow to the left lower limb , resulting in pain and cramping due to intermittent claudication.
  • • Option C
  • • left femoral artery
  • • adductor tubercle
  • • lead
  • • reduced blood flow
  • • left lower limb
  • • pain
  • • cramping
  • • intermittent claudication.
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • In cases of arterial blockage , collateral circulation often develops to bypass the obstruction . The profunda femoris artery , particularly its perforating branches , plays a crucial role in forming collateral circulation around a blocked femoral artery . These branches provide alternative pathways for blood flow , potentially reducing the severity of symptoms.

questions.text: Patient undergoing treatment for Borderline tuberculoid leprosy presented with papular lesion on (frontal & maxillary area) forehead, nose extending bilateral to cheeks with sensory involvement. Which nerve is involved:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Trigeminal nerve

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. The Facial nerve, or seventh cranial nerve (CN VII), primarily controls the muscles of facial expression . It also provides some sensory function for the external ear and has parasympathetic fibers . While the Facial nerve does affect the facial region, its primary role is motor control rather than sensation. The patient's symptoms are more aligned with sensory involvement, which is less indicative of Facial nerve pathology.
  • • Option B.
  • • seventh cranial nerve (CN VII),
  • • muscles of facial expression
  • • sensory function
  • • external ear
  • • parasympathetic fibers
  • • primary role
  • • motor control
  • • Option C. The Transverse Cervical nerve arises from the cervical plexus , typically from the second and third cervical nerves . It provides sensation to the anterior neck . The distribution of the lesion in the patient does not align with the innervation territory of the Transverse Cervical nerve, which is focused on the neck area and not the face.
  • • Option C.
  • • arises
  • • cervical plexus
  • • second
  • • third cervical nerves
  • • sensation
  • • anterior neck
  • • Option D. The Ventral ramus of the second cervical nerve (C2) forms part of the cervical plexus and contributes to the innervation of the neck . Similar to the Transverse Cervical nerve, the Ventral ramus of C2 is involved in innervating the neck area, not the facial regions described in the patient's symptoms.
  • • Option D.
  • • second cervical nerve (C2)
  • • cervical plexus
  • • contributes
  • • innervation of the neck

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The Trigeminal nerve, also known as the fifth cranial nerve (CN V), is primarily responsible for sensation in the face . It has three branches : the ophthalmic (V1), maxillary (V2), and mandibular (V3) branches. The description of the lesions on the forehead , nose , and extending bilaterally to the cheeks correlates with the areas innervated by the Trigeminal nerve, specifically the ophthalmic and maxillary branches . The sensory involvement further supports this, as the Trigeminal nerve is a key sensory nerve for the face.
  • ➤ The Trigeminal nerve, also known as the fifth cranial nerve (CN V), is primarily responsible for sensation in the face . It has three branches : the ophthalmic (V1), maxillary (V2), and mandibular (V3) branches.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents to the clinic with complaints of recurrent episodes of fatigue, dizziness, and syncope, especially during physical activity. On examination, her blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg, and a systolic murmur is heard along the left sternal border. An echocardiogram reveals severe aortic stenosis. Right coronary artery origin part was affected. Where does the right coronary artery originate from?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Anterior Aortic Sinus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Posterior Aortic Sinus is located just above the aortic valve . The right coronary artery does not arise from this sinus. Instead, it's typically the non-coronary sinus or occasionally the left coronary artery that is associated with the posterior aortic sinus .
  • • Option A.
  • • above
  • • aortic valve
  • • typically
  • • non-coronary sinus
  • • left coronary artery
  • • posterior aortic sinus
  • • Option B. Coronary Sinus is on the posterior aspect of the heart . The right coronary artery is not connected to the coronary sinus as it is an artery, not a vein.
  • • Option B.
  • • posterior aspect
  • • heart
  • • Option C. Left Aortic Sinus, also known as the left posterior aortic sinus . This sinus is typically the origin of the left coronary artery . The left coronary artery branches into the left anterior descending artery and the circumflex artery , supplying blood to the left side of the heart .
  • • Option C.
  • • left posterior aortic sinus
  • • origin
  • • left coronary artery
  • • left anterior descending artery
  • • circumflex artery
  • • left side
  • • heart

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anterior Aortic Sinus, also known as the right anterior aortic sinus , is the correct origin of the right coronary artery . The right coronary artery arises from this sinus and travels down the right side of the heart, supplying blood to the right atrium, right ventricle, part of the left ventricle , the sinoatrial node and the atrioventricular node .
  • ➤ Anterior Aortic Sinus, also known as the right anterior aortic sinus , is the correct origin of the right coronary artery .
  • ➤ right anterior aortic sinus
  • ➤ right coronary artery
  • ➤ The right coronary artery arises from this sinus and travels down the right side of the heart, supplying blood to the right atrium, right ventricle, part of the left ventricle , the sinoatrial node and the atrioventricular node .

  • ➤ left ventricle

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman was admitted for a large swelling which was found to extend downward and medially below the left costal margin. On percussion, a continuous band of dullness was noted to extend upward from the left of the umbilicus to the left axillary region. On palpation, a notch was felt along the anterior border of the swelling. A diagnosis of splenic enlargement was made. Which of the following statements pertaining to the above case is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: The spleen is situated in the Upper Left Quadrant of the Abdomen beneath the Diaphragm.

options.label: B
options.text: The Long Axis of the Spleen lies along the 10 th Rib

options.label: C
options.text: A pathologically enlarged Spleen extends downward and forward, toward the Left Iliac Fossa.

options.label: D
options.text: The Spleen has a notched Anterior Border caused by Incomplete Fusion of its parts during Development.

questions.correct_answer: C. A pathologically enlarged Spleen extends downward and forward, toward the Left Iliac Fossa.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) A pathologically enlarged Spleen extends downward and forward, toward the Left Iliac Fossa.

questions.text: A 63-year-old female with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents with palpitations and occasional dizziness. She denies any chest pain or shortness of breath. Her family history is significant for sudden cardiac death in her brother at the age of 50. On examination, her heart rate is irregular, and an ECG shows episodes of non-sustained ventricular tachycardia. An echocardiogram reveals mild right ventricular dilation with preserved ejection fraction. The patient's condition is related to abnormality of following cell junctions at marked area except.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Zona Occludens

Explanation:

  • • Explanations:
  • • Option A. Gap Junctions are a key component of intercalated discs . Gap junctions allow for direct cytoplasmic connections between adjacent cardiac muscle cells . It enables the rapid and coordinated spread of electrical impulses across the cardiac muscle . This synchronized contraction is essential for effective heart pumping .

  • • Option C. Fascia Adherens are ribbon like protein structure that connect and bind cardiac muscle cells . They are broad intercellular junctions that anchor actin filaments . They are found at the peripheral region of cellular attachment where actin filaments of the I-band insert and terminate . They form large portion of intercalated disc , the structure at which myofibrils terminate in cardiomyocytes.
  • • Option C.

They are critical for maintaining the structural integrity of the heart during its relentless pumping action . They are composed of dense plaques of protein attached to the cell membrane, linked to intermediate filaments within the cell , providing strong mechanical attachment between cells .

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with elevated cholesterol levels and a history of alcohol abuse. questions.text: ​​​​​ A 36-year-old male presents to clinic for a routine health check-up. He has no significant past medical history and leads an active lifestyle. During his respiratory examination, you note the following parameters: His respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute, tidal volume is measured at 400 mL, and dead space volume is estimated to be 150 mL. What is the patient's alveolar ventilation per minute?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 4000 mL

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option C:
  • • Option C:
  • • The alveolar ventilation per minute can be defined as the total volume of new air entering the alveoli in one minute . The alveolar ventilation per minute can be expressed as Alveolar ventilation per min = (Tidal volume - dead space) x rate of respiration Here, tidal volume = 400 mL, respiratory rate = 16/min Dead space volume = 150 mL Alveolar ventilation /min = (400 - 150) x 16 = 250 x 16 = 4000 mL

questions.text: In cardiac diagnostics, clinicians often refer to the LDH isoenzyme ratio as an indicator of myocardial infarction (MI). In a typical healthy adult, the LDH-2 level is higher than LDH-1. A condition where this ratio is reversed, with LDH-1 being higher than LDH-2, is sometimes described in clinical practice. Is the term "flipped pattern" correctly applied to the scenario where LDH-2 is higher than LDH-1?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. False

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Healthy individual has LDH-2 higher than LDH-1. After certain types of myocardial injury, such as an MI, cardiac cells release more LDH-1 than LDH-2, which can lead to LDH-1 becoming higher than LDH-2. This reversal is what's referred to as a "flipped pattern," so the statement LDH-2 >>> LDH-1 being known as a flipped pattern is false.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ This question tests understanding of LDH isoenzyme patterns in normal and pathological states. The five LDH isoenzymes (LDH-1 through LDH-5) consist of different combinations of H (heart) and M (muscle) subunits. LDH-1 (H₄) predominates in heart tissue, LDH-5 (M₄) predominates in liver and skeletal muscle, and the others are hybrid forms. The normal serum pattern (LDH-2 > LDH-1) gets reversed in myocardial infarction, creating the "flipped pattern" (LDH-1 > LDH-2). While historically important, LDH isoenzyme analysis has been largely replaced by more specific cardiac markers such as troponin in modern clinical practice.
  • ➤ Ref : Harper 30/e: p 69.
  • ➤ Ref

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes a key aspect of the active site of an enzyme?

options.label: A
options.text: It forms the half of the potion of enzyme

options.label: B
options.text: It binds with substrate by non-covalent bonds

options.label: C
options.text: It is not usually a cleft or crevices

options.label: D
options.text: Binding of substrate to the site is independent of the alignment of specific groups.

questions.correct_answer: B. It binds with substrate by non-covalent bonds
questions.explanation:
Ans. B.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. It forms half of the portion of the enzyme: This statement is inaccurate . The active site usually comprises only a small portion of the enzyme's total volume , specifically tailored for substrate binding and catalysis.
  • • Option A. It forms half of the portion of the enzyme:
  • • inaccurate
  • • active site
  • • small portion of the enzyme's total volume
  • • Option C. It is not usually a cleft or crevice: Contrary to this statement, the active site is often a cleft or crevice on the enzyme's surface . This structural feature allows the active site to accommodate the substrate molecule (s) and exclude water , which is crucial for many enzymatic reactions.
  • • Option
  • • C. It is not usually a cleft or crevice:
  • • active site
  • • cleft or crevice on the enzyme's surface
  • • structural feature
  • • active site to accommodate the substrate molecule
  • • exclude water
  • • Option D. Binding of the substrate to the site is independent of the alignment of specific groups: This statement is incorrect. The binding of the substrate to the active site is highly dependent on the precise alignment and orientation of specific amino acid residues and functional groups within the active site . This specificity ensures that only particular substrates can bind and be catalytically transformed by the enzyme.
  • • Option
  • • D. Binding of the substrate to the site is independent of the alignment of specific groups:
  • • binding
  • • substrate to the active site
  • • precise alignment
  • • orientation
  • • amino acid residues
  • • functional groups within the active site

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The region of the enzyme where substrate binding and catalysis takes place is known as active site or active centre and it contains substrate binding site and catalytic site. Though all parts are required for maintaining the three-dimensional structure of the enzyme, the reaction is taking place at the active site and it occupies only a small portion of the whole enzyme. Active site is situated in a crevice or cleft of the enzyme molecule. To the active site, substrate is bound and the binding depends on the alignment of specific groups or atoms at active site and these groups realign themselves to provide the unique conformational orientation so as to promote exact fitting of substrate to the active site. The substrate binds to the enzyme at the active site by noncovalent bonds and are hydrophobic in nature. The amino acids or groups which directly participate in making or breaking the bonds (present at the active site) are known as catalytic residues or catalytic groups.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the Michaelis constant (Km)?

options.label: C
options.text: Not a characteristic feature of enzymes

options.label: D
options.text: A low Km value indicates a weak affinity of the enzyme for enzyme-substrate complex formation.

questions.correct_answer: B. Substrate concentration at half-maximal velocity
questions.explanation:
Ans. B.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Substrate concentration at maximum velocity: This statement is incorrect. The substrate concentration at maximum velocity is not specifically defined by Km , as Vmax is reached at much higher substrate concentrations where all enzyme active sites are saturated.
  • • Option A. Substrate concentration at maximum velocity:
  • • substrate concentration
  • • maximum velocity
  • • not specifically defined by Km
  • • Option C. Not a characteristic feature of enzymes: This statement is incorrect. Km is indeed a characteristic feature of enzymes and is crucial in the study of enzyme kinetics.
  • • Option
  • • C. Not a characteristic feature of enzymes:
  • • Km
  • • characteristic feature of enzymes
  • • Option D. A low Km value indicates a weak affinity of the enzyme for enzyme-substrate complex formation: This statement is incorrect. A low Km value actually indicates a high affinity of the enzyme for its substrate, as it means the enzyme can achieve half-maximal velocity at a lower substrate concentration.
  • • Option
  • • D. A low Km value indicates a weak affinity of the enzyme for enzyme-substrate complex formation:
  • • low Km value
  • • high affinity of the enzyme
  • • substrate,

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Salient features of Km:
  • ➤ Salient features of Km:
  • ➤ Km value is substrate concentration (expressed in moles/L) at half-maximal velocity. It denotes that 50% of enzyme molecules are bound with substrate molecules at that particular substrate concentration. It is independent of enzyme concentration . It is the signature of the enzyme. Km value is thus a constant for an enzyme and it is the characteristic feature of a particular enzyme for a specific substrate. The affinity of an enzyme towards its substrate is inversely connected to the dissociation constant, Kd for the enzyme-substrate complex. Km denotes the affinity of enzymes for substrates . So, less the numerical value of Km, the affinity of the enzyme for the substrate is more.

questions.text: A 27-year-old biochemistry graduate student is presenting her findings on enzyme kinetics at a regional conference. She displays a Lineweaver-Burk plot as part of her presentation, highlighting the utility of this type of graph in determining enzyme kinetics constants. She points out the x-intercept and asks her audience to identify what this value corresponds to in terms of Michaelis-Menten kinetics. Which of the following is equal to the x-intercept in a Lineweaver-Burk plot?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Km​: This is incorrect because Km​ itself is not represented by the x-intercept ; rather, its negative reciprocal is.
  • • Option
  • • A. Km​:
  • • Km​
  • • not represented by the x-intercept
  • • Option C. Km​/Vmax​: This option is incorrect. While both Km​ and Vmax​ are parameters of the Michaelis-Menten equation , the ratio Km​/Vmax​ is not represented by the x-intercept in a Lineweaver-Burk plot.
  • • Option
  • • C. Km​/Vmax​:
  • • Km​ and Vmax​ are parameters
  • • Michaelis-Menten equation
  • • Option D. 1/Vmax​: This is incorrect because the y-intercept represents 1/Vmax ​, not the x-intercept.
  • • Option
  • • D. 1/Vmax​:
  • • y-intercept represents 1/Vmax

  • ➤ With “Double Reciprocal Plot” sometimes it is difficult to achieve high substrate concentrations to reach the maximal velocity conditions . So, ½ Vmax or Km is difficult to determine thus experimental data at lower concentrations is plotted as reciprocals a straight line is obtained when extrapolated to get the reciprocal of Km . This is called Lineweaver Burk Plot or Double Reciprocal Plot which can be derived from the Michaelis-Menten equation. If we plot 1/v against 1/[S], it will give a straight-line graph. X intercept is (-1/Km), from which the Km can be calculated.
